author: RICHARD MONTENEGRO BROWN
title: EARTHQUAKES: Experts jolted by ‘99.9%’ quake forecast
text:
By RICHARD MONTENEGRO BROWN / STAFF WRITER
Published: Oct. 23, 2015 Updated: 11:37 p.m. EARTHQUAKES: Experts jolted by ‘99.9%’ quake forecast Print Photo Share Pin It 1 of 3 More Galleries ADVERTISEMENT Javon Comas, 12, takes cover at Jones Elementary in San Bernardino in this year's Great California ShakeOut. , KURT MILLER, STAFF PHOTOGRAPHER Related article » GETTING READY • Pick safe places in each room of your home, workplace and/or school. It could be under a piece of furniture or against an interior wall.
• Practice "drop, cover and hold on" in each safe place.
• Keep a flashlight and sturdy shoes by each person's bed in case the earthquake strikes in the middle of the night.
• Bolt and brace water heaters and gas appliances to wall studs.
• Learn how to shut off the gas valves in your home and keep a wrench handy for that purpose.
• Learn about your area's seismic building standards and land-use codes before you begin new construction.
• Keep and maintain an emergency-supplies kit in an easy-to-access location.
Source: American Red Cross
WHEN THE SHAKING STOPS • Expect and prepare for potential aftershocks or landslides.
• Each time you feel an aftershock, drop, cover and hold on.
• Put on long pants, a long-sleeve shirt, sturdy shoes and work gloves to protect against injury.
• Have a portable, battery-operated or hand-crank radio for emergency information and instructions.
• Look for and extinguish small fires. Fire is the most common hazard after an earthquake.
• Clean up spilled medications, bleach, gasoline or other flammable liquids immediately.
• Watch out for fallen power lines or broken gas lines and stay out of damaged areas.
• Stay out of damaged buildings.
• If you were away from home, return only when authorities say it is safe to do so.
Source: American Red Cross
If the last few days have shown seismologist Robert Graves anything, it’s that the one certainty in the science of earthquakes is uncertainty.
“Precise prediction is not possible right now,” said Graves, coordinator for earthquake hazards in Southern California for the U.S. Geological Survey in Pasadena, “and I don’t know that it will ever be.”
Graves and his colleagues at USGS responded to countless inquiries in the wake of a report declaring a “99.9 percent” likelihood of a large earthquake hitting the greater Los Angeles area in the next three years. In a field riddled with caveats, “99.9 percent” constitutes the kind of “virtual certainty” that is simply not possible, Graves said.
The study, a team effort from UC Irvine and the Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Pasadena, projected a magnitude 5.0 or greater temblor within a 62-mile radius of the 2014 La Habra earthquake by 2018. On the outer rim of that big circle sit Riverside and San Bernardino counties.
The impact of such a quake in La Habra would be minimal on the Inland Empire, Graves said. It would be felt, “but I would be surprised if there was a major effect,” he said.
“It’s important not to read too much into this 60-mile circle. There is nothing special about that,” he said. “It’s an arbitrary choice made by these researchers.”
The NASA-led study – published earlier this month in the American Geophysical Union journal Earth and Space Science and publicized this week – asserts there is enough stored seismic energy in the network of faults linked to the La Habra quake to generate a quake of magnitude 6.1 to 6.3.
The research simply affirms the basic conclusion that Southern California is primed for a big earthquake. The tools developed over the past decade by USGS and others have forecast an 85 percent probability that a magnitude 5 or better will happen in that same area and along the same time frame.
Despite criticism of the report, no one, from NASA to USGS to local leaders, believes that Inland residents should be any less prepared for “the Big One.”
Riverside County officials are keenly aware of the NASA study, and it hasn’t changed how the county is preparing one way or another, said Kim Saruwatari, director of the county’s emergency management department.
“I think that at the end of the day, whether it’s the 85 percent number or the 99.9 percent number, the message for emergency management is that we need to maintain a constant state of readiness,” she said, “and understand that earthquakes can happen at any time.”
Readiness for Saruwatari means constant assessment of the county’s emergency response procedures and spreading the gospel of readiness to residents.
On Oct. 15, that included participating in the Great California ShakeOut drill. Just over 620,000 residents and workers in Riverside County and 668,000 in San Bernardino County registered to participate, according to the event’s website.
“Readiness is important no matter what percentage or probability,” echoed Craig Petinak, spokesman for the Riverside County Office of Education. “That is why we encourage schools to participate … increase the readiness in case something does happen.”
Graves doubts there will be a way to truly predict an earthquake in his lifetime. Preparedness, he said, is paramount.
“I wake up each day recognizing that we can have a large earthquake. It’s a fact of living in Southern California.”
